update.description:
This pull request creates the base of operations (BOO).

The BOO is derived from RobotPlugin, so it inherits all the communication capabilities. The BOO should use `<address>boo</address>` in all the world files. Any robot can send a message to the BOO using the target address `kBoo` and the destination port `kBooPort`. 

The BOO supports commands with syntax: `<CMD> [args]`. Right now, only the `FOUND` command is supported with the following syntax:

```
#!python

FOUND <x> <y> <z> <t> : Person found in [x,y,z] at time t, where:

x: X coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
y: Y coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
z: Z coordinate of the lost person in world coordinates (meters).
t: Time at which the person was spotted (double).
```
E.g.: FOUND 100.0 50.0 1.0 10.4

The BOO keeps track of the history of the lost person's positions along time. The world has been discretized and the BOO stores the coordinates of the cells that the lost person is traversing and the time that entered that cell for the first time. The buffer only stores changes in the cells.

Additionally, the robots are only allowed to communicate FOUND commands with times no older than the current time - `kMaxDt`. The buffer of positions also uses this constant to recycle elements when possible.

When a FOUND message is dispatched, the reported position is converted to a 3D cell. We consider success when this cell matches the cell stored in the buffer. After success, a message is published on topic /swarm/found with the address of the robot that found the person, time, and its position. Also, the simulation is paused.
update.title: Boo

content.html:
I see boo test failures.

/home/nkoenig/work/swarm/test/integration/boo.cc:93: Failure
Value of: found
  Actual: false
Expected: true

content.raw: A comment on the cell discretization: it looks like we'll have trouble at cell boundaries.  If the real pose is very close to one edge of a cell and I guess a pose very close to the other side of the edge in a neighboring cell, the BOO will reject it.    This is probably OK as long as we're using exact information (true robot pose + person pose observed through perfect camera), but if we add any noise, we'll need to adjust the technique to be based on a Euclidean distance metric.
content.html: A comment on the cell discretization: it looks like we'll have trouble at cell boundaries. If the real pose is very close to one edge of a cell and I guess a pose very close to the other side of the edge in a neighboring cell, the BOO will reject it. This is probably OK as long as we're using exact information (true robot pose + person pose observed through perfect camera), but if we add any noise, we'll need to adjust the technique to be based on a Euclidean distance metric.

Additionally, the robots are only allowed to communicate FOUND commands with times no older than the current time - `kMaxDt`. The buffer of positions also uses this constant to recycle elements when possible.

When a FOUND message is dispatched, the reported position is converted to a 3D cell. We consider success when this cell matches the cell stored in the buffer. After success, a message is published on topic /swarm/found with the address of the robot that found the person, time, and its position. Also, the simulation is paused.
